Row.Text: Napoleon wakes in the night, dreams still clouding his mind. A tiny man, bright red in color, had perched upon his chest and read to him the fate of the world: a world lit by lightning, where men fly and the stars descend to burn the earth.[n][n]The firelight gutters in the low bronze braziers. Napoleon struggles to remember the last part. “As for you,” the dream-man had said, “you will take this world, and…”
Napoleon's ideas span many topics, but at the end of the day, they all result in profits.
Strength opens doors to new allies. But to Napoleon, they are new ears to listen to his commands.
A dream is but a dream.
“The world is chaos,” the red man of destiny whispers to Bonaparte. And, indeed, the world is full of illogic and superstition – its people follow symbols, rather than ideas.
It is time to wake up the people.
As Napoleon's people leave superstition behind, they find new avenues in life that bring prosperity to his empire.

“The world is chaos,” the red man of destiny whispers to Bonaparte. And, indeed, the landscape is a patchwork of petty, would-be kings and tyrants. What these smaller powers lack is vision.[n][n]Napoleon, while he may have his shortcomings, does not lack in vision.
Napoleon's bonfires strike fear in enemies' hearts, and attract friends like moths to a flame.

Gazing at his city from the base of the Great Pyramids, Napoleon sees the full extent of his lands – and those that have yet to submit to his reign. War calls out to him, but greatness may also be achieved through alternative measures.
Bloodshed is not always the answer.

The legions of Napoleon stream through the streets of their newest settlement. Now his power resonates across the known world, the first step in a long journey – the foundation of empire that will linger forever.
All must know of this victory.

Napoleon watches his ships disappear beneath the waves, and with them, his letters home – and those of his soldiers. But someone thought to rescue them from a watery fate, and soon these private confessions appear in translation, published by the enemy!
Personal secrets are nothing to be ashamed of.
What is greatness in a leader – the ambition to reform society, or the strength to conquer the world? Whatever his path, Napoleon knows that history sits in his hands.
A rotten core must be replaced.

In the temple halls, the songs of the priests ring out, and the faithful gather. Napoleon sits in the back, dressed plainly, watching and listening. In the front, a man weeps disconsolately, overcome by emotion. “What do you think of all this?” his advisor whispers.
Napoleon's temples are marvels, dripping in gold and gems. They are not merely symbols of the divine on earth, but daily reminders to the people of his authority.
It is blindness to material truth.

Napoleon's stablehand has had too much to drink. He begins a litany of complaints to all who can hear: "The things I have picked out of Marengo’s hooves? Thorns. Ice. Red clay. White clay. Nails. Bullets. Once – a live tarantula! Quelle malchance! What will be next?”
Across land and ocean, Napoleon's steed Marengo trods the world round. In his wake, merchants gleefully collect the riches from even the most distant shores.
Neither harsh terrain nor stormy weather can halt the spread of Bonaparte's power. His army marches onward, enthralled by his command, seeking only to satisfy his grand vision of dominance.
Napoleon's armies take root in new lands. Now he is ready to negotiate.
Capture a Settlement in Distant Lands.
War is condoned by the divine.

The cannon thunder echoes off of the distant cliffs. Bonaparte looks on, a faint twitch at the corner of his mouth betraying his pleasure. “Larger?” his engineer asks. “No,” responds the First Consul. “More."
Napoleon prefers to speak with his enemies first. But should disagreements arise, his artillery takes charge of the conversation.

Councillors pause their hot debate over the construction of new bridge to watch Napoleon's small knife at work. As he listens, queries, and argues, the blade channels his energy, disappearing into the arm of his chair again and again. One fellow, staring at the deep gouges, suggests they take a break for the sake of everyone's nerves. "Nonsense," Napoleon waves him off. "Now where do we stand on surgeons?"
The bridge issue should be resolved first.

Aides-de-camp stand to attention in the commander's tent as Napoleon peers into one of many large mahogany boxes. He runs his fingers across its velvet lining, then along the leather spines of the books within. Ignoring the panting soldiers depositing the final crate of tomes, he shakes his head. He is surrounded by hundreds of books – but such an inquisitive mind requires thousands.
A new set must be published, with smaller print and no margins.

Napoleon parades through the streets of the conquered city. Its citizens watch in silence, worried for their futures and what will become of their traditions. Local religious leaders beg that their beliefs, at least, remain intact.
Why change what makes the people happy?

Napoleon Bonaparte is a hero for a rational age, where a single man of daring and ambition can stand alone against the forces of reaction – or so the newspapers report. The radical pamphlets tell a different tale: a cosmetic revolution, one where authority hides behind a revolutionary’s cockade. Not a tragedy, but a farce.
Dissidents may whisper what they will. But anyone who lays eyes on the grandeur of Napoleon's empire knows that he, and he alone, is authority.
Napoleon Bonaparte, the self-made emperor, a monarch stripped bare of the finery of monarchy down to the bones of niter and lead. The crown he wears is one he placed upon his own head.
Napoleon's firepower is fearsome, yet his words command more attention than the loudest explosion. All listen when he speaks…or else.
Train a Biplane, Trench Fighter, and Bomber.

Countless footsteps crunch in the snow as Napoleon's army marches through their newly conquered land. Soldiers marvel at the good weather that accompanied their campaign, and the well-organized supply lines that kept them healthy and fed. Some even argue that the lessons learned from this war are more valuable than the bounty that awaits them in the city.
This experience will be valuable in future campaigns.
This settlement holds many great works of art…

Across the French Empire, people practice law according to their own traditions. Some draw from historical codices while others rely on common law. Napoleon has had enough of this chaos. It is time for a single code – a Code civil des Français.
This process takes time to complete properly.
The sooner these reforms take hold, the better.

Napoleon stares at the statue before him. An ancient god of war, gifted with his own likeness, gazes back. The representation is exquisite. But the physique is not flattering…nor is its near nudity. As the figure is carried away to the bowels of the palace, never to see the light of day, he compensates the sculptor heartily and sends him on his way.
The arts speak the truth of human spirit.
One must be careful with wishes.

As much as Napoleon surrounds himself with generals, so too does he engage the greatest of learned minds. Science, literature, music, and theology…his expertise in these subjects surprises and delights their masters.
Intellectual pursuits must be available to all.
